## 2.4. Other relevant regulatory frameworks
### 2.4.1. Specific branches of international law
There are additional international law regimes that are relevant to the regulation of cyber-attacks in specific circumstances. International telecommunication regulations prohibit interference with broadcasts of authorized frequencies of other states, as well as harmful interferences that endanger radio-navigation or radio-communication service or other radio safety services, or seriously degrade, obstruct or repeatedly interrupt such services. Cyber-attacks that disrupt telecommunication infrastructure may violate these international regulations. Still, international telecommunications regulations do not prohibit, as a rule, attacks aimed at military radio.
Cyber-attacks aimed at disruption of air traffic control and flight passenger lists might implicate international aviation law. Cyber operations that target civilian flights also run contrary to this international regime. In the same vein, cyber-attacks directed against submarine cables implicate the international law of the sea, which requires states to punish those who damage them. Also prohibited are unauthorized broadcasting from the high seas, which may cover certain marine-based cyber-attacks. Given the very specific circumstances in which these provisions apply, they provide minimal protections in the face of cyber-attacks.

## 3. The attribution challenge
When confronted with a cyber-attack, States can choose to respond through cyber tools, such as hack-backs, resort to kinetic military force or engage in diplomacy. A preliminary issue, regardless of the type of response selected is attribution. This is since establishing the identity of the attacker is crucial to direct a response against it.
For example, a victim state to a violation of international law which does not amount to an armed attack, is permitted to take non-forceful proportionate countermeasures against the violating state provided it can legally attribute the original attack to it or show it violated its DD obligations. Lawful countermeasures are measures that would normally be considered themselves as a violation of international law, but their wrongfulness is precluded when they come in response to a prior unlawful act (provided that they are notified as such and are proportionate to the violation). They are an important self-help tool for states, in a decentralized international legal system. Still, as indicated above, states might prefer not to disclose evidence – even if doing so is critical for attribution. So, although advancements have been made in regard to the technical ability to attribute cyber-attacks, political will to publicly make legal attribution is often lacking.

Part of the attribution problem derives from the structural design of the Internet, and the processes through which data is transmitted between networks, which offers excellent conditions for maintaining anonymity. Attackers can, for example, delay being discovered by using ‘logic bombs’, and perform attacks via intermediaries in other jurisdictions. They can also harness zombie computers, use proxy servers or resort to ‘spoofing’ tools (incorporating a misleading return address by the sender). When a cyber-attacker employs techniques, such as ‘proxy’ or ‘Stepping Stones’, the available forensic evidence might not be enough to allow technical attribution. The difficulty in obtaining forensic evidence from computer systems under the control of other states is another factor. Hence, only states with access to sophisticated forensic investigative capacities and strong intelligence services are well-positioned to succeed in undertaking technical attribution. International law currently provides a relatively weak regulatory framework and there is a need for clearer rules that prohibit and respond to cyber-attacks, including rules that delineate what cyber-attacks constitutes an unlawful armed attack, and legal procedures that facilitate the proving and attributing of cyber-attacks. Greater reliance on international law offers states the possibility of dealing with cyber threats through public diplomacy and multilateral sanctions – policy options that go over and beyond self-reliance on passive and active cyber defense. The ability to rely on an effective international law framework might encourage states to accept reciprocal restraints in cross-border cyber operations and to exercise more intensive control over non-state actors active in this field.
Alas, it will not be an easy task to promote an international agreement specifying the application of international law rules to cyber operations. For example, Russia proposed in the past an international treaty that will ban secretly embedding malicious codes for future use in case of a need, but the US opposed it. Other significant challenges relate to disagreement about the structure of the Internet (i.e., and the extent of ‘digital sovereignty’ over parts thereof) and attribution. An international instrument regulating cyber-attacks could promote greater harmonization of practices and better cooperation, including information sharing, and criminal prosecution. Such an instrument can also incentivize tech-savvy states to advise and assist less-developed ones, and promote the creation of an independent international attribution mechanism which would minimize factual disagreements and de-escalate international conflict. Despite the many challenges ahead, the project of strengthening international regulation of cyber-attacks should not be discarded.

# International Regulation of Cyber Operations
## Yuval Shany and Tal Mimran
## 1. Introduction
Cyberspace constitute an unstable environment, featuring rapid changes in the nature of the actors using it, the technologies applied and the inter-personal, governmental and commercial interactions facilitated thereby. The nature of the threats posed by those who abuse cyberspace is also highly dynamic in nature.¹ At the same time, the growing reliance of individuals, markets and society at large on digital devices (including on the Internet of things), and on networks which connect them to one another, generates high susceptibility in the face of malicious cyber-operations (also referred to as cyber-attacks).² The global COVID-19 pandemic exponentially accelerated the trend of digitalization in various fields of life, increasing even more the dependency on cyber-infrastructure and with it the potential for harmful cyber-attacks.³
Traditionally, states have been cautious in invoking international law in the context of cyber-attacks, and they tended to refrain from denouncing attacks against them as violations of international law, or attributing it to other states.⁴ Such reluctance appears to derive primarily from political and operational considerations: enhancing the regulatory role of international law in cyberspace might impede espionage activities resorted to by all states, and limit the retaliation options of victim states.⁵ Another reason for the reluctance might be the lack of a credible international attribution mechanism for hostile cyber operations.⁶ Instead, states targeted by cyber-attacks resort at times to private companies providing technical attribution aimed at identifying the computer system from which the attack had originated, followed by

1. A Short History of Cyber-attacks
It is hard to exaggerate the crucial role cyberspace plays in almost all aspects of everyday life. AI systems relying on online databases and computer networks facilitate the management of huge amounts of governmental services, economic transactions, health data and more.¹⁹ The recent COVID-19 pandemic accelerated digitalization of fields like workplace meetings, distant teaching and online shopping.²⁰

## 2. The International Law Framework governing Cyber-attacks
Cyberspace has been characterized by some as a domain devoid of normative limitations.⁹⁶ This is because Internet and other cyber-infrastructures allegedly operate as a global network that is beyond the sovereign control of any specific state and there is no international cooperation agreement underlying its existence or manner of operation (unlike other international infrastructure such as telephone systems).⁹⁷ While, in the future, a new branch of law specifically aimed at regulating the conduct of all relevant stakeholders in cyberspace (lex cybernetica) might emerge,⁹⁸ legal experts and state officials – especially, officials coming from victim states that have much more to lose from cyber-attacks than their attackers – have attempted to fill the normative void by adjusting existing rules of international law to the challenges posed by cyber-attacks.

## 2.1. Due diligence
As a starting point, a state should not allow its territory to be used to violate the rights of other states – including via hostile cyber operations. This international law obligation of due-diligence (DD) requires a state to take reasonable measures to safeguard its territory from being to misused to commit violations of international law.¹⁰¹ If such violations nonetheless occur, then the state should investigate them properly, and provide a remedy to the victims.¹⁰² Based on the DD principle, states should prevent non-state actors, or other states, from conducting cyber-attacks from within their territory.¹⁰³ A failure to meet DD obligations might give rise to a violation of international law, even if the harm was done in practice by private persons or entities.¹⁰⁴ DD is an obligation of conduct, not one of result, in the sense that it demands from the state to employ all means reasonably available to it.¹⁰⁵ It sets a standard of conduct that depends on state capacity and its actual ability to operate.¹⁰⁶ This standard was recognized by states such as Finland,¹⁰⁷ France,¹⁰⁸ and Germany, as applicable to cyber-attacks.¹⁰⁹

## 2.2.2. Cyber-attacks and the prohibition on the use of force
The applicability to cyberspace of the prohibition against the use of force, as well as the self-defense exception, are reaffirmed in rules 10 and 13 of the Tallinn Manual,¹³⁸ and is supported by a recent UN Group of Governmental Experts report.¹³⁹ Yet, there are three main approaches, in the academic literature, to the application of the right to self-defense against an armed attack in the context of cyber-attacks: 1) the instrument-based approach; 2) the target-based approach; and 3) the effects-based approach.¹⁴⁰
The instrument-based approach categorizes an act as an armed attack giving rise to the right to self-defense only if the harm it causes has characteristics traditionally associated with the harm caused by military force.¹⁴¹ While this approach promotes predictability,¹⁴² it is perceived as outmoded.¹⁴³ The second approach, the target-based approach, classifies a cyberattack against critical infrastructure as an armed attack, regardless of its consequences.¹⁴⁴ It

## 2.3. Cyber-attacks and the non-intervention principle
Another important principle of international law regulating cyber-attacks and responses thereto is the principle of non-intervention. According to this principle, states are entitled to conduct key domestic government functions (domaine réservé) without foreign interference.¹⁷⁷ And while, it has been observed that, in practice, this non-intervention principles is often honored in the breach,¹⁷⁸ it is nevertheless a key component of the international legal order.¹⁷⁹ Cyber operations have opened new avenues of intervention in the internal affairs of foreign states, including manipulation of elections (e.g., the 2016 intervention in the US Presidential elections),¹⁸⁰ bringing into focus claims about violation of the principle of non-intervention.¹⁸¹

## 2.4. Other relevant regulatory frameworks
### 2.4.1. Specific branches of international law
There are additional international law regimes that are relevant to the regulation of cyber-attacks in specific circumstances.¹⁸³ International telecommunication regulations prohibit interference with broadcasts of authorized frequencies of other states, as well as harmful interferences that endanger radio-navigation or radio-communication service or other radio safety services, or seriously degrade, obstruct or repeatedly interrupt such services.¹⁸⁴ Cyber-attacks that disrupt telecommunication infrastructure may violate these international regulations. Still, international telecommunications regulations do not prohibit, as a rule, attacks aimed at military radio.¹⁸⁵
Cyber-attacks aimed at disruption of air traffic control and flight passenger lists might implicate international aviation law.¹⁸⁶ Cyber operations that target civilian flights also run contrary to this international regime.¹⁸⁷ In the same vein, cyber-attacks directed against submarine cables implicate the international law of the sea, which requires states to punish those who damage them.¹⁸⁸ Also prohibited are unauthorized broadcasting from the high seas,¹⁸⁹ which may cover certain marine-based cyber-attacks. Given the very specific circumstances in which these provisions apply, they provide minimal protections in the face of cyber-attacks.¹⁹⁰

## 2.4.2. International organizations
International organizations serve as important venues for regulating cyber-attacks and responses thereto. At the UN level, several General Assembly resolutions dealt with developments in cyberspace,¹⁹¹ and the General Assembly initiated, since 2004, six Groups of Governmental Experts (GGE) sessions aimed at identifying international law principles applicable in cyberspace.¹⁹² The most recent round of GGE meetings began on 2019 and included the permanent members of the Security Council and government experts from other countries, selected based on the principle of equitable geographical representation.¹⁹³ The recent report of the Group highlighted the need to respect in cyberspace the following UN Charter principles: 1) sovereign equality; 2) the settlement of disputes by peaceful means; 3) the prohibition against the use of force; and 4) non-intervention.¹⁹⁴ The General Assembly also established in 2018 an Open-ended Working Group, open to all UN members, to consider ways to advance international cooperation in light of new developments in cyberspace.¹⁹⁵

## 3. The attribution challenge
When confronted with a cyber-attack, States can choose to respond through cyber tools, such as hack-backs,²⁰⁷ resort to kinetic military force or engage in diplomacy. A preliminary issue, regardless of the type of response selected is attribution.²⁰⁸ This is since establishing the identity of the attacker is crucial to direct a response against it.
For example, a victim state to a violation of international law which does not amount to an armed attack, is permitted to take non-forceful proportionate countermeasures against the violating state provided it can legally attribute the original attack to it or show it violated its DD obligations.²⁰⁹ Lawful countermeasures are measures that would normally be considered themselves as a violation of international law, but their wrongfulness is precluded when they come in response to a prior unlawful act (provided that they are notified as such and are proportionate to the violation).²¹⁰ They are an important self-help tool for states,²¹¹ in a decentralized international legal system.²¹² Still, as indicated above, states might prefer not to disclose evidence – even if doing so is critical for attribution.²¹³ So, although advancements have been made in regard to the technical ability to attribute cyber-attacks,²¹⁴ political will to publicly make legal attribution is often lacking.²¹⁵

The legal framework governing the attribution of responsibility of states was codified in the ARSIWA,²¹⁶ which is largely reflective of customary international law.²¹⁷ State responsibility can usually arise when acts are performed by an organ of the state, persons entrusted with governmental authority, or pursuant to state instructions, direction or control.²¹⁸ States can also be responsible for acts that they acknowledged and adopted as their own.²¹⁹
There are some noteworthy challenges when applying the ARSIWA framework to cyber-attacks. Part of the attribution problem derives from the structural design of the Internet, and the processes through which data is transmitted between networks, which offers excellent conditions for maintaining anonymity.²²⁰ Attackers can, for example, delay being discovered by using ‘logic bombs’, and perform attacks via intermediaries in other jurisdictions.²²¹ They can also harness zombie computers,²²² use proxy servers or resort to ‘spoofing’ tools (incorporating a misleading return address by the sender).²²³ When a cyber-attacker employs techniques, such as ‘proxy’ or ‘Stepping Stones’, the available forensic evidence might not be enough to allow technical attribution.²²⁴ The difficulty in obtaining forensic evidence from computer systems under the control of other states is another factor.²²⁵ Hence, only states with access to sophisticated forensic investigative capacities and strong intelligence services are well-positioned to succeed in undertaking technical attribution.²²⁶ Still, the context of the attack might sometimes be strongly suggestive of the identity of the perpetrator. ## 4. The way forward
The evolving nature of cyberspace and technology invites constant assessment of the applicable regulatory frameworks, including regulation of cyber-attacks. The threat of cyber-

attacks, capable of shutting down economic activity and media and communication networks, or disrupting commerce and impair governmental activity, is ever-present and ubiquitous in the digital age, and the recent COVID-19 crisis illustrated the growing dependency of information societies on digital technology and network connectivity. While cyber-security, cyber-diplomacy, technical training and education are of importance, experience in other fields related to international conflicts shows that effective regulation aimed at shaping the conduct of state and non-state actors is also of great importance.
International law currently provides a relatively weak regulatory framework and there is a need for clearer rules that prohibit and respond to cyber-attacks, including rules that delineate what cyber-attacks constitutes an unlawful armed attack, and legal procedures that facilitate the proving and attributing of cyber-attacks. Greater reliance on international law offers states the possibility of dealing with cyber threats through public diplomacy and multilateral sanctions – policy options that go over and beyond self-reliance on passive and active cyber defense. The ability to rely on an effective international law framework might encourage states to accept reciprocal restraints in cross-border cyber operations and to exercise more intensive control over non-state actors active in this field.
Alas, it will not be an easy task to promote an international agreement specifying the application of international law rules to cyber operations. For example, Russia proposed in the past an international treaty that will ban secretly embedding malicious codes for future use in case of a need, but the US opposed it.²⁴⁰ Other significant challenges relate to disagreement about the structure of the Internet (i.e., and the extent of ‘digital sovereignty’ over parts thereof) and attribution. An international instrument regulating cyber-attacks could promote greater harmonization of practices and better cooperation, including information sharing, and criminal prosecution.²⁴¹ Such an instrument can also incentivize tech-savvy states to advise and assist less-developed ones,²⁴² and promote the creation of an independent international attribution mechanism which would minimize factual disagreements and de-escalate international conflict. Despite the many challenges ahead, the project of strengthening international regulation of cyber-attacks should not be discarded.

## Yuval Shany and Tal Mimran
## 1. Introduction
Cyberspace constitute an unstable environment, featuring rapid changes in the nature of the actors using it, the technologies applied and the inter-personal, governmental and commercial interactions facilitated thereby. The nature of the threats posed by those who abuse cyberspace is also highly dynamic in nature.¹ At the same time, the growing reliance of individuals, markets and society at large on digital devices (including on the Internet of things), and on networks which connect them to one another, generates high susceptibility in the face of malicious cyber-operations (also referred to as cyber-attacks).² The global COVID-19 pandemic exponentially accelerated the trend of digitalization in various fields of life, increasing even more the dependency on cyber-infrastructure and with it the potential for harmful cyber-attacks.³
Traditionally, states have been cautious in invoking international law in the context of cyber-attacks, and they tended to refrain from denouncing attacks against them as violations of international law, or attributing it to other states.⁴ Such reluctance appears to derive primarily from political and operational considerations: enhancing the regulatory role of international law in cyberspace might impede espionage activities resorted to by all states, and limit the retaliation options of victim states.⁵ Another reason for the reluctance might be the lack of a credible international attribution mechanism for hostile cyber operations.⁶ Instead, states targeted by cyber-attacks resort at times to private companies providing technical attribution aimed at identifying the computer system from which the attack had originated, followed by

This state of affairs appears to be changing, however. While there are of disagreements as to the way that international law applies in the cyberspace, a common understanding had emerged about some key international law norms that apply in this field.⁸ States like Australia,⁹ France,¹⁰ Germany,¹¹ Israel,¹² the United Kingdom,¹³ and the Netherlands¹⁴ have recently articulated their legal positions on how international law applies in cyberspace. In the same vein, states who fell victim to cyber-attacks are increasingly attributing them, as an international law matter, to other states, or non-state actors.¹⁵ Arguably, the increased role played by international law in cyberspace constitutes a reaction to the fact that cyber-attacks become more and more frequent, and dangerous, capable of shutting down critical infrastructure,¹⁶ including nuclear centrifuges¹⁷ and water pumping facilities.¹⁸ ⁷ Israel asserts that attribution remains a mostly technical matter that should not be overregulated, and that the choice of disclosing information supporting attribution claims remains at the exclusive discretion of the state. Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3961263 This chapter will describe and critically evaluate the norms of international law which regulate cyber-operations, and discuss some of the policy considerations underlying them. Part I offers a short history of cyber-attacks. Part II presents the current international law framework governing cyber-attacks. Part III delves into the attribution challenge in cyberspace. Part IV concludes and suggests a way forward.

It is hard to exaggerate the crucial role cyberspace plays in almost all aspects of everyday life. AI systems relying on online databases and computer networks facilitate the management of huge amounts of governmental services, economic transactions, health data and more.¹⁹ The recent COVID-19 pandemic accelerated digitalization of fields like workplace meetings, distant teaching and online shopping.²⁰ Against this background, it is no surprise that cyber-attacks can and do cause significant and widespread damage.²¹ Notable attacks from recent years were directed against nuclear infrastructure²² and other basic utilities,²³ hospitals,²⁴ commercial entities,²⁵ Internet services²⁶ and more. Significantly, the mix between public and private entities also exists on the attacking side. The relative low costs of conducting cyber-attacks³⁹ and the ability to maintain a high Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3961263 degree of anonymity while engaging in such attacks,⁴⁰ renders resort to such attacks an available and attractive option in the eyes of criminals, hacktivists and political extremists. As will be elaborated in the part below dealing with attribution, tracing attacks back to their source is not an easy task even for states with advanced cyber capabilities.⁴¹ In fact, the low entry barrier for developing cyber-attack capabilities allows militarily weaker parties to international conflicts, including non-state actors,⁴² to ‘bridge the gap’ and take on powerful states (who may, paradoxically, be more vulnerable to cyber-attacks because of their greater reliance on online services and platforms).⁴³ Moreover, at times, states use non-state actors to perform cyber operations at their behest, with a view to hiding their own involvement.⁴⁴ Cyber-attacks can take a variety of forms, entailing different types of harms and inviting different preventive measures and regulatory responses. A highly common form of a cyberattack is a Distributed Denial of Service (DDOS) operation, during which botnets devastate computer servers through large scale repeat visits to designated websites.⁴⁵ DDOS attacks come in many forms, including network flooding, data modification, electromagnetic interference and more.⁴⁶ Famous DDOS attacks are the attacks conducted during April 2007 on the densely wired Estonia, as well as attacks in Georgia during 2008, ahead of the Russian invasion to South Ossetia.⁴⁷ Nashi – a youth-movement supporting Russian President Putin – accepted responsibility for the attacks,⁴⁸ which appear to have been motivated by political reasons related to tensions in Estonian-Russian relations. More recently, hospitals around the globe faced DDOS attacks during the Covid-19 pandemic; the motives underlying such attacks are less than clear. 
A more sophisticated form of cyber-attack is a syntactic attack that involves malware that manipulates and damages the operation of computer systems.53 A prime example is Stuxnet,54 which was described as a joint US and Israeli effort.55 Stuxnet was a malware that infiltrated Iranian nuclear facilities in or before 2010 in order to destroy centrifuges used for uranium enrichment.56 It disrupted the systems at the nuclear facilities,57 and destroyed centrifuges while sending false signals that disabled safety systems in place.58 Stuxnet was the first syntactic attack directed against security infrastructure.59 Unlike previous cyber-attacks, such as the one in Estonia, Stuxnet caused significant damage to physical objects.60 Beyond that, there are other cyber-operations that may qualify as cyber-attacks. Recently though, the tide seems to be turning. A growing number of states outlined their legal views as to the way in which international law governs cyberspace. Examples include statements by Australia, Finland, France, Germany, Israel, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and New Zealand. This change may be attributed in part to the rise in cyber-attacks around the world during the Covid-19 crisis. The health-care sector has proved itself particularly vulnerable to cyber-attacks and hospitals, other health-care facilities and research institutions involved in developing vaccines were targeted by hostile cyber operations. In addition, cyber-attackers directed their attention towards international organizations involved in responding to the crisis, most notably the World Health Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3961263 Organization,⁹³ complicating international efforts to cope with the pandemic.⁹⁴ Another problem that arose during the crisis was the spread on-line of disinformation campaigns.⁹⁵ In sum, cyber-attacks pose a growing threat for states and their critical infrastructure. As a result, there is greater urgency in regulating threat and harm-generating cyber-operations and the responses of the victim state. We will now refer to some international legal instruments which are provide the framework for regulation of cyber-attacks and state responses to them.
## 2. The International Law Framework governing Cyber-attacks Cyberspace has been characterized by some as a domain devoid of normative limitations.⁹⁶ This is because Internet and other cyber-infrastructures allegedly operate as a global network that is beyond the sovereign control of any specific state and there is no international cooperation agreement underlying its existence or manner of operation (unlike other international infrastructure such as telephone systems).⁹⁷ While, in the future, a new branch of law specifically aimed at regulating the conduct of all relevant stakeholders in cyberspace (lex cybernetica) might emerge,⁹⁸ legal experts and state officials – especially, officials coming from victim states that have much more to lose from cyber-attacks than their attackers – have attempted to fill the normative void by adjusting existing rules of international law to the challenges posed by cyber-attacks.
We will now present shortly some international law norms which might be of relevance to regulating cyber-attacks, and discuss in this connection international instruments, such as the United Nations (UN) Charter,⁹⁹ and the International Law Commission Articles on State Responsibility for Internationally Wrongful Acts ("ARSIWA").¹⁰⁰ Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3961263 As a starting point, a state should not allow its territory to be used to violate the rights of other states – including via hostile cyber operations. This international law obligation of due-diligence (DD) requires a state to take reasonable measures to safeguard its territory from being to misused to commit violations of international law.¹⁰¹ If such violations nonetheless occur, then the state should investigate them properly, and provide a remedy to the victims.¹⁰² Based on the DD principle, states should prevent non-state actors, or other states, from conducting cyber-attacks from within their territory.¹⁰³ A failure to meet DD obligations might give rise to a violation of international law, even if the harm was done in practice by private persons or entities.¹⁰⁴ DD is an obligation of conduct, not one of result, in the sense that it demands from the state to employ all means reasonably available to it.¹⁰⁵ It sets a standard of conduct that depends on state capacity and its actual ability to operate.¹⁰⁶ This standard was recognized by states such as Finland,¹⁰⁷ France,¹⁰⁸ and Germany, as applicable to cyber-attacks.¹⁰⁹ ## 2.2. Use of force and non-intervention To the extent that cyber operations constitute an integral part of the reality of armed conflicts,¹¹⁰ there is little question that the laws that apply to armed conflicts also apply to aggressive and defensive cyber operations. ## 2.2.1. Prohibition on the use of force and non-intervention – general The prohibition against the use of force in international law, which is a *jus cogens* (peremptory) norm,¹¹⁸ is enshrined in Article 2(4) of the UN Charter.¹¹⁹ There are two exceptions to the prohibition which are stipulated in the Charter: (1) Authorization by the Security Council (SC) under the collective security system; (2) Individual self-defense or collective self-defense against an armed attack.¹²⁰ There is some debate regarding the existence of additional exceptions.¹²¹ Cyberattack on Iranian Port Facility, WASHINGTON POST, 18 May 2020, available at: https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/officials-israel-linked-to-a-disruptive-cyberattack-on-iranian-port-facility/2020/05/18/9d1da866-9942-11ea-89fd-28fb313d1886_story.html.

2) the target-based approach; and 3) the effects-based approach.¹⁴⁰ The instrument-based approach categorizes an act as an armed attack giving rise to the right to self-defense only if the harm it causes has characteristics traditionally associated with the harm caused by military force.¹⁴¹ While this approach promotes predictability,¹⁴² it is perceived as outmoded.¹⁴³ The second approach, the target-based approach, classifies a cyberattack against critical infrastructure as an armed attack, regardless of its consequences.¹⁴⁴ It Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3961263 ignores the actual effects of the attack and places all emphasis on the nature of the target.¹⁴⁵ Critical infrastructure includes computer systems central to the operation of the banking, health, transportation and management of natural resources sectors.¹⁴⁶ Whereas the instrument-based approach has been criticized for placing too high the bar for armed attacks, target-based approach has been criticized for placing the bar too low, facilitating thereby unnecessary escalation of international conflicts.¹⁴⁷ The third approach, the effects-based approach, constitutes the middle road between the other two approaches and is, perhaps not surprisingly, the dominant of the three.¹⁴⁸ Under this approach, a cyber-attack can constitute an armed attack which may be responded to by force based on several criteria, elaborated by Schmitt:¹⁴⁹ the degree of physical destruction; temporal proximity between the attack and its consequences; the existence of a direct link between the damage and the attack; the level of invasiveness of the attack; and measurability of the harm. For example, a victim state to a violation of international law which does not amount to an armed attack, is permitted to take non-forceful proportionate countermeasures against the violating state provided it can legally attribute the original attack to it or show it violated its DD obligations.²⁰⁹ Lawful countermeasures are measures that would normally be considered themselves as a violation of international law, but their wrongfulness is precluded when they come in response to a prior unlawful act (provided that they are notified as such and are proportionate to the violation).²¹⁰ They are an important self-help tool for states,²¹¹ in a decentralized international legal system.²¹² Still, as indicated above, states might prefer not to disclose evidence – even if doing so is critical for attribution.²¹³ So, although advancements have been made in regard to the technical ability to attribute cyber-attacks,²¹⁴ political will to publicly make legal attribution is often lacking.²¹⁵ Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3961263 There are some noteworthy challenges when applying the ARSIWA framework to cyber-attacks. Part of the attribution problem derives from the structural design of the Internet, and the processes through which data is transmitted between networks, which offers excellent conditions for maintaining anonymity.²²⁰ Attackers can, for example, delay being discovered by using ‘logic bombs’, and perform attacks via intermediaries in other jurisdictions.²²¹ They can also harness zombie computers,²²² use proxy servers or resort to ‘spoofing’ tools (incorporating a misleading return address by the sender).²²³ When a cyber-attacker employs techniques, such as ‘proxy’ or ‘Stepping Stones’, the available forensic evidence might not be enough to allow technical attribution.²²⁴ The difficulty in obtaining forensic evidence from computer systems under the control of other states is another factor.²²⁵ Hence, only states with access to sophisticated forensic investigative capacities and strong intelligence services are well-positioned to succeed in undertaking technical attribution.²²⁶ Still, the context of the attack might sometimes be strongly suggestive of the identity of the perpetrator. The way forward The evolving nature of cyberspace and technology invites constant assessment of the applicable regulatory frameworks, including regulation of cyber-attacks. The threat of cyber- Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3961263 International law currently provides a relatively weak regulatory framework and there is a need for clearer rules that prohibit and respond to cyber-attacks, including rules that delineate what cyber-attacks constitutes an unlawful armed attack, and legal procedures that facilitate the proving and attributing of cyber-attacks. Greater reliance on international law offers states the possibility of dealing with cyber threats through public diplomacy and multilateral sanctions – policy options that go over and beyond self-reliance on passive and active cyber defense. The ability to rely on an effective international law framework might encourage states to accept reciprocal restraints in cross-border cyber operations and to exercise more intensive control over non-state actors active in this field.
Alas, it will not be an easy task to promote an international agreement specifying the application of international law rules to cyber operations. For example, Russia proposed in the past an international treaty that will ban secretly embedding malicious codes for future use in case of a need, but the US opposed it.²⁴⁰ Other significant challenges relate to disagreement about the structure of the Internet (i.e., and the extent of ‘digital sovereignty’ over parts thereof) and attribution. An international instrument regulating cyber-attacks could promote greater harmonization of practices and better cooperation, including information sharing, and criminal prosecution.²⁴¹ Such an instrument can also incentivize tech-savvy states to advise and assist less-developed ones,²⁴² and promote the creation of an independent international attribution mechanism which would minimize factual disagreements and de-escalate international conflict. Despite the many challenges ahead, the project of strengthening international regulation of cyber-attacks should not be discarded.

metadata.abstract: =3961263 This chapter will describe and critically evaluate the norms of international law which regulate cyber-operations, and discuss some of the policy considerations underlying them. Part I offers a short history of cyber-attacks. Part II presents the current international law framework governing cyber-attacks. Part III delves into the attribution challenge in cyberspace. Part IV concludes and suggests a way forward.
